interaction_summary:
=== Purchase Information ===
Review Date: 2018/10/08
Average Rating: 4.1
Product Details: {'Content advisory': ['Violence'], 'Subtitles': ['None available'], 'Directors': ['Sally Howell'], 'Producers': ['Heather Dreiling', 'Eric Schotz', 'Kathy Williamson'], 'Studio': ['MagellanTV']}
Review Text: The narrator, who looks like the kind of guy who got beat up a lot in grammar school, is a little too alarmist, and rehashes  stuff the main authority on sugar has already talked about. This goofball says he is serious about exercise and then says who needs a gym and walks up a hill with rocks. Wow. I've lived in England, and just like the rest of English TV, this seems like, I don't know- practice television, and a practice documentary. Also what I've noticed in English documentaries, they seem to be fascinated by the narrator WALKING. It must be a luxury in the UK to walk, or it must denote thinking. Anyway, I couldn't make it all the way through.
Review Title: Couldn't make it to the end
Rating: 2.0
--------------------------------------------------

It's a sweet movie with a little R ish material, not too much, but all in all a nice escape, and a movie that stands up to rewatching. It's a sweet movie with a little R ish material {'Subtitles': ['None available'], 'Directors': ['Henry Singer'], 'Producers': ['Henry Singer'], 'Studio': ['XiveTV']} They should retitle this one "The Most Narcissistic Photographer in the History of Photographs". This guy tried to make the entire story about him, a guy who pushed a button on a machine. Line after line of how he was Picasso, how his photograph compared to Pulitzer Prize winning photos, every last thing the guy said was about himself. I defy you to find a sentence without the word "I" or "me" in it. The Most Narcissistic Photographer in the History of Photographs {'Content advisory': ['Violence', 'foul language'], 'Audio languages': ['English'], 'Subtitles': ['English [CC]'], 'Directors': ['Stephanie Kaim'], 'Producers': ['Irène Challand', 'Claire Colart', 'Sandrine Delegiewicz', 'Stéphane Haumant', 'Gaspard Lamunière', 'Daniel Leconte', 'Andreas Lemos', 'Émilie Raffoul', 'Olivier Stroh'], 'Studio': ['MagellanTV']} Out after 40 seconds. I at first couldn't realize if the video was warped, or the guy had a speech impediment. No way could I make it through 90 minutes of that. Out after 40 seconds. I at first couldn't realize ... {'Content advisory': ['Violence', 'frightening scenes', 'foul language'], 'Audio languages': ['English'], 'Subtitles': ['English [CC]'], 'Directors': ['None'], 'Starring': ['Ruth Blackwell'], 'Studio': ['Independent Documentary']} Water faucets running and junk scattered on the floor. That HAD to be a ghost! I now believe in ghosts! This was a lower budget Blair Witch Project that was hoping a large percentage of the people were too young to remember The Blair Witch Project. The only reason it barely made it to three stars is that it's a cute couple. And they did get me to watch the whole thing. This was very terrible. This was very terrible. {'Content advisory': ['Alcohol use', 'foul language', 'sexual content'], 'Audio languages': ['English'], 'Subtitles': ['English [CC]'], 'Directors': ['Lee Schloss'], 'Producers': ['Mike Bocchetti'], 'Starring': ['Mike Bocchetti', 'Artie Lange', 'Sal the Stockbroker']} The quality of the video could be better, but the quality of Mike could not. He's got a heart of gold, and if you want to see who he is, I recommend youtubing "Mike Bocchetti and the weather". Crisp video quality, and Mike never has a bad word to say about anyone. His true comic talents are brought out by Artie Lange on Artie's show when he does the weather. Please watch, I've seen it so many times. Mike is a 5 star person {'Content advisory': ['Foul language'], 'Audio languages': ['English'], 'Subtitles': ['English [CC]'], 'Directors': ['CJ Wallis'], 'Producers': ['Mallory Kennedy', 'CJ Wallis'], 'Starring': ['Ted Slauson', 'Bob Barker', 'Roger Dobkowitz']} The guy who does the narrating (the principle subject) has this style that doesn't seem like he'd like any kind of game show at all. But it kind of grows on you. There is a surprising amount of footage that captures all of his appearances. I thought there would be a little more scandal to it. It really should be titled The Contestant Who Knew a Fair Amount. There were some tones of stalker in him, but that helped my fascination. And Holly didn't have to fear him because well, ya know, I mean- ya know? She knew.

Also, at the time when he was young, he was a good looking guy, I think that's how the models kind of liked him. In his prime, it wasn't weird to ask for a kiss from Holly. It was really sad to see Bob Barker get older, because you see the pics of him when he was younger, and you just couldn't look more alive. For even someone that good looking to get old, damn, what's that say for the rest of us.

But I highly recommend this doc for sure for sure watch it. A really good documentary {'Content advisory': ['Violence'], 'Subtitles': ['None available'], 'Directors': ['Sally Howell'], 'Producers': ['Heather Dreiling', 'Eric Schotz', 'Kathy Williamson'], 'Studio': ['MagellanTV']} The narrator, who looks like the kind of guy who got beat up a lot in grammar school, is a little too alarmist, and rehashes stuff the main authority on sugar has already talked about. This goofball says he is serious about exercise and then says who needs a gym and walks up a hill with rocks. Wow. I've lived in England, and just like the rest of English TV, this seems like, I don't know- practice television, and a practice documentary. Also what I've noticed in English documentaries, they seem to be fascinated by the narrator WALKING. It must be a luxury in the UK to walk, or it must denote thinking. profile:
**User Summary:**

The user maintains a strong preference for comedy films that blend drama and nostalgia, emphasizing narratives rich in personal connections and cultural experiences. Their refined taste underscores a passion for balanced storytelling and character exploration, alongside a notable aversion to self-absorbed protagonists.

Recent interactions indicate an increasing intolerance for poorly executed filmmaking, demanding emotional engagement and narrative clarity more than ever before. While they might still recognize redeeming qualities such as strong lead performances, they are now less forgiving of subpar content. Their commitment to nuanced storytelling is evident through engagement with multi-language audio and subtitles, reinforcing their desire for accessible narratives.

A recent interaction highlights their admiration for an engaging narrator despite production shortcomings, suggesting they value genuine contributions from individuals in the entertainment realm but maintain high standards for quality. However, their critical lens has expanded to encompass broader issues of production quality, evident in their dissatisfaction with certain documentary formats that they find lackluster or overly simplistic in execution.

Overall, this profile outlines a sophisticated viewer who prizes quality storytelling and character depth while exhibiting a growing scrutiny of narrative coherence and filmmaking execution. They seek films that evoke warmth and explore complex themes but are increasingly uncompromising in their expectations for emotional impact and entertainment value.
